latestVersion.termsOfUse:
Individual researchers interested in using Parivartan data should first present their ideas in the form of a concept sheet below. The concept sheet will form the basis of the paper, research questions, variables requested, methods and names of the proposed co-authors. All research that individual researchers wish to publish must have been approved by an appropriately constituted review team led by the Project PI, Dr. Kim Blankenship. As appropriate, authorship details should be discussed with the PI. The concept sheet should be submitted to kim.blankenship@american.edu.

___ (hereafter Researcher), at___ , has requested data from Project Parivartan to conduct analysis for ___ . The Researcher has submitted a concept sheet entitled, that has been approved by the review committee, led by Dr. Kim Blankenship, Principal Investigator, Project Parivartan. Researcher agrees that s/he will maintain full confidentiality of the data in accordance with the accepted norms and practices of academic research; Researcher agrees that s/he will use the data solely for the purpose of conducting analysis as made explicit in the approved concept sheet; Researcher agrees that s/he will, at all times, maintain the confidentiality of all data provided and keep the data in a secure location; Researcher agrees that s/he will destroy the data provided to her/him when it is no longer needed for the purpose of the aforementioned analysis; Researcher agrees that the disclosure, dissemination or sharing of data to, or with, any other person or entity except with the Researcher's mentor and other faculty advisors, without prior permission of project PI, is not permissible; Researcher agrees that s/he will provide a copy of the final research outcome to the project PI; Researcher will acknowledge the source of and funding for the data in the final research product in the following terms: Data for this analysis is provided by Project Parivartan, a research project led by Dr. Kim Blankenship and based at American University, Center on Health, Risk and Society, Department of Sociology.

fields.value: Project Parivartan: Research on the Implementation and Impact of Structural Interventions for HIV Prevention among Female Sex Workers in Southern India

authorAffiliation.value: American University, Sociology Department, Center on Health, Risk and Society

datasetContactAffiliation.value: Center on Health, Risk and Society, American University

dsDescriptionValue.value: Project Parivartan, which means long-term change, as well as metamorphosis, conducts research on the implementation of structural interventions among female sex workers in the state of Andhra Pradesh, India. It is supported by the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation as part of Avahan India AIDS Initiative. The project's overall goal is to contribute in reduction of HIV risk among at-risk Female Sex Workers (FSWs) through the analysis of structural interventions that focus on altering the context within which individuals engage in health behaviors or make health-related decisions. The Parivartan team includes an interdisciplinary team, whose members are comprised of sociologists, anthropologists, and public health experts based in India and the U.S. at several academic institutions. The project is currently based at American University's Center on Health, Risk and Society (CHRS), and is led by Principal Investigator Kim M. Blankenship, Professor and Chair, Department of Sociology, and Director of CHRS. The surveys were conducted in spring of 2006, the spring of 2007, and the winter of 2009-10. The total participants were 812, 673 and 850 respectively in rounds I, II and III of the survey. To be included in the study, participants had to identify as a female sex worker; report being no less than 18 years of age; report exchanging sex for money at least once in the year prior to the interview; submit a study coupon to intervention staff before interview could occur. No STI/HIV-testing or other bio-marker data were collected. Interviews lasted approximately 90 minutes and were conducted in the local language (Telugu) by trained interviewers, following participants providing informed consent. Following each interview, participants were provided with correct information related to HIV/AIDS and STI risks and received appropriate referrals to local services. It is important to note that while the implementing NGOs' emphasis was on developing and implementing interventions as quickly and effectively as possible, Parivartan was a research project with no implementation responsibilities. Parivartan's goals were to systematically document and analyze these initiatives. The research was approved by the Duke University Health Systems Institutional Review Board, the Yale University Human Investigations Committee, the Institutional Review Board at American University, and the VHS-YRG Care Medical Centre Institutional Review Board in Chennai, India.

keywordValue.value: Community mobilization, Female sex workers (FSWs), HIV, HIV prevention, India, Risk, Structural factors, Structural interventions;  INSTITUTION: American University; STRATEGIC AREAS: Behavioral tracking surveys, Community mobilization in-depth research

topicClassValue.value: Demographics and sex work histories; Types and frequency of sexual exchanges; Condom use by FSWs with clients and other sexual partners;Use of services by FSWs;Extent of collective empowerment of FSWs; Attitudes and beliefs among sex workers about such things as work, health, and relationships;Experience of violence and discrimination against FSWs; Police attitudes, practices, and policies towards FSWs ;Degree of sex worker involvement with ongoing interventions for sex workers.

distributorAffiliation.value: American University, Center on Health, Risk and Society

value:
Parivartan research has been published in a wide range of journals. The survey data in particular have examined a wide range of structural factors such as economic insecurity, policing practices, housing instability, and motherhood responsibility affecting FSW risk to HIV. Survey data has also examined the role of community mobilization efforts by FSWs in influencing structural inequalities that produce HIV risk. Please refer to publication citation section. Proj
ect Parivartan has also come up with several policy briefs that highlight various contextual factors leading to HIV risk. The briefs are based on its published peer-reviewed articles and are available for download at: http://www.projectparivartan.org/

otherGeographicCoverage.value: Rajahmundry, East Godavari district in Andhra Pradesh state, India

fields.value: Given the nature of sex work, women in the sample were recruited using Respondent Driven Sampling (RDS), a chain-referral technique that is designed to reach hidden populations. Five FSWs were chosen by the research team in the field, and in collaboration with Care-Saksham, as seeds, or as the initial recruits for participation in the survey. The seeds, after completing the survey, were then provided three number-tracked coupons each to give to women from their personal networks who met the study inclusion criteria. Each successive participant was also given three coupons to recruit other women into the study until the desired sample size was reached. Women received monetary remuneration for completing the survey and for each successful recruit (up to 3) who completed the survey.
Data were collected through self-administered questionnaire.

files.description: The three rounds of survey codebook are to help individual researchers to identify when a variable name or coding of a variable changed between rounds, or when a variable was not included in a subsequent round of the survey.  The codebook also makes it easier and less intimidating for new researchers to identify and use data that they are interested in analyzing.  Subsequent to which, researchers can complete the attached concept sheet to request the release of data.
